articles.headline: San Francisco Mayor Declares State of Emergency to Fight City’s ‘Nasty Streets’
articles.snippet: It’s a highly unusual move by a liberal mayor in one of the country’s most liberal cities.
articles.abstract: It’s a highly unusual move by a liberal mayor in one of the country’s most liberal cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The mayor of San Francisco on Friday made a sharp break with the liberal conventions that have guided her city for decades, declaring a state of emergency in one of its most crime-infested neighborhoods.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller, Shaila Dewan and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Appeals Court Reinstates OSHA’s Vaccine Mandate for Workers at Larger Businesses
articles.snippet: The decision, by a split three-judge panel, overturned a ruling that had blocked a Biden administration rule requiring companies with 100 or more employees to mandate vaccinations or testing for workers.
articles.abstract: The decision, by a split three-judge panel, overturned a ruling that had blocked a Biden administration rule requiring companies with 100 or more employees to mandate vaccinations or testing for workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel on Friday reinstated a Biden administration rule requiring larger companies to mandate that their workers get vaccinated against the coronavirus or submit to weekly testing by early January.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Emma Goldberg and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: With Omicron, U.S. Testing Capacity Faces Intense Pressure
articles.snippet: President Biden came into office vowing to make testing cheap and accessible, but matching supply with demand has been a persistent problem.
articles.abstract: President Biden came into office vowing to make testing cheap and accessible, but matching supply with demand has been a persistent problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s coronavirus testing capacity, already straining to keep up with demand, is facing enormous new pressure, with holiday travelers waiting in long lines to be tested, overworked laboratories struggling to keep up and rapid at-home diagnostics flying off pharmacy shelves as the Omicron variant fuels a rapid spike in Covid-19 cases.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Early Decision Isn’t Binding. Let Us Explain.
articles.snippet: If you can’t afford the price a college quotes you, you don’t have to go. We corrected an N.Y.U. blog post and rewrote the Common App for you.
articles.abstract: If you can’t afford the price a college quotes you, you don’t have to go. We corrected an N.Y.U. blog post and rewrote the Common App for you.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early decision acceptance notices have just gone out from many highly rejective — they prefer “selective” — colleges, which means a lot of families are now trying to figure out how they’re going to make it work financially.

articles.headline: As Covid Surges, Experts Say U.S. Booster Effort Is Far Behind
articles.snippet: The C.D.C. now recommends that all adults get a booster. But only one in six Americans has received that shot, worrying health officials.
articles.abstract: The C.D.C. now recommends that all adults get a booster. But only one in six Americans has received that shot, worrying health officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Nine months ago, the lines stretched out the doors at Dr. Rusty Oshita’s three urgent care clinics, teeming with patients frantic to get vaccinated against Covid-19.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Amy Harmon

articles.headline: Map by Map, G.O.P. Chips Away at Black Democrats’ Power
articles.snippet: Black elected officials in several states, from Congress down to the counties, have been drawn out of their districts this year or face headwinds to hold onto their seats.
articles.abstract: Black elected officials in several states, from Congress down to the counties, have been drawn out of their districts this year or face headwinds to hold onto their seats.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 30 years ago, Robert Reives Sr. marched into a meeting of his county government in Sanford, N.C., with a demand: Create a predominantly Black district in the county, which was 23 percent Black at the time but had no Black representation, or face a lawsuit under the Voting Rights Act.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: It’s Been a Home for Decades, but Legal Only a Few Months
articles.snippet: California catches up with the reality that when it’s too hard to play by the rules, people convert the garage into an apartment anyway.
articles.abstract: California catches up with the reality that when it’s too hard to play by the rules, people convert the garage into an apartment anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: On paper, the converted garage behind the Martinez family home in the Boyle Heights section of Los Angeles is a brand-new unit of housing, the product of statewide legislation that is encouraging homeowners to put small rental homes on their property and help California backfill its decades-old housing shortage. Two stories tall with 1,100 square feet of living space that is wrapped in a curved exterior wall, adorned with pops of pink around the windows and decorative white squares, it looms over the squat main house as a statement of something different behind a chain-link fence.

articles.headline: Can a ‘Very Confident’ Carrie Lam Salvage Her Legacy in Hong Kong?
articles.snippet: Mrs. Lam is Hong Kong’s most unpopular leader ever, blamed for mass protests and a political crackdown. Yet she now appears reinvigorated, perhaps even ready for a second term.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Lam is Hong Kong’s most unpopular leader ever, blamed for mass protests and a political crackdown. Yet she now appears reinvigorated, perhaps even ready for a second term.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The students sat quietly as soldiers goose-stepped into the Hong Kong high school’s auditorium, hoisting a Chinese flag. The M.C.s spoke in Mandarin, the language of mainland China, rather than Cantonese, the city’s predominant language. Then Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s chief executive, took the podium, to extol the importance of patriotism in the city’s youth.

articles.headline: Hidden Pentagon Records Reveal Patterns of Failure in Deadly Airstrikes
articles.snippet: The promise was a war waged by all-seeing drones and precision bombs. The documents show flawed intelligence, faulty targeting, years of civilian deaths — and scant accountability.
articles.abstract: The promise was a war waged by all-seeing drones and precision bombs. The documents show flawed intelligence, faulty targeting, years of civilian deaths — and scant accountability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The promise was a war waged by all-seeing drones and precision bombs. The documents show flawed intelligence, faulty targeting, years of civilian deaths — and scant accountability.

articles.headline: Britney Spears Felt Trapped. Her Business Manager Benefited.
articles.snippet: Louise Taylor faces questions about whether she improperly enriched herself as the pop star’s business manager.
articles.abstract: Louise Taylor faces questions about whether she improperly enriched herself as the pop star’s business manager.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early 2008, a small-time Tennessee company with big-time aspirations made a loan to Britney Spears’s father, who for years had struggled financially.
articles.byline: By Liz Day, Emily Steel, Rachel Abrams and Samantha Stark

articles.headline: Manchin Pulls Support From Biden’s Social Policy Bill, Imperiling Its Passage
articles.snippet: The West Virginia senator’s comments dealt a potentially fatal blow to the centerpiece of the president’s domestic agenda, and drew a broadside from the White House.
articles.abstract: The West Virginia senator’s comments dealt a potentially fatal blow to the centerpiece of the president’s domestic agenda, and drew a broadside from the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, said on Sunday that he could not support President Biden’s signature $2.2 trillion social safety net, climate and tax bill, dooming his party’s drive to pass its marquee domestic policy legislation as written.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: The Path Ahead for Biden: Overcome Manchin’s Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: A key Democrat’s decision to pull support from the president’s sprawling climate and social agenda is rooted in the scope of the bill.
articles.abstract: A key Democrat’s decision to pull support from the president’s sprawling climate and social agenda is rooted in the scope of the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III, the West Virginia Democrat, effectively killed President Biden’s signature domestic policy bill in its current form on Sunday, saying he was convinced the spending and tax cuts in the $2.2 trillion legislation will exacerbate already hot inflation.

articles.headline: Zegna’s I.P.O. Path Raises Question: Is This the Next Big Fashion Trend?
articles.snippet: In a sign of the luxury industry’s revival from pandemic lows, the company went public through a SPAC on Monday.
articles.abstract: In a sign of the luxury industry’s revival from pandemic lows, the company went public through a SPAC on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ermenegildo Zegna is bringing a new luxury product to the New York Stock Exchange: itself. And it is doing it in the most financially trendy way.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Brandon Just Wants to Drive His Racecar
articles.snippet: “I have zero desire to be involved in politics,” says Brandon Brown, the NASCAR driver at the center of the “Let’s Go, Brandon!” meme.
articles.abstract: “I have zero desire to be involved in politics,” says Brandon Brown, the NASCAR driver at the center of the “Let’s Go, Brandon!” meme.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODFORD, Va. — “What actually keeps you from getting any nausea is that you’re so zoned in on just doing this,” Brandon Brown said, speaking for himself after noticing that I’d barely avoided throwing up into my mask.

articles.headline: Whiplash on U.S. Vaccine Mandate Leaves Employers ‘Totally Confused’
articles.snippet: Companies are struggling to figure out what to do as legal battles and rising Covid cases complicate their plans. Even up in the air: What does “fully vaccinated” mean?
articles.abstract: Companies are struggling to figure out what to do as legal battles and rising Covid cases complicate their plans. Even up in the air: What does “fully vaccinated” mean?
articles.lead_paragraph: The marching orders from the Biden administration in November had seemed clear — large employers were to get their workers fully vaccinated by early next year, or make sure the workers were tested weekly. But a little over a month later, the Labor Department’s vaccine rule has been swept into confusion and uncertainty by legal battles, shifting deadlines and rising Covid case counts that throw the very definition of fully vaccinated into question.
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Emma Goldberg and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Billions in Amtrak Funding Could Modernize Aging Rail System
articles.snippet: The $1 trillion infrastructure bill that President Biden signed into law includes money that Amtrak hopes can fix crumbling bridges and tunnels along the Northeast Corridor.
articles.abstract: The $1 trillion infrastructure bill that President Biden signed into law includes money that Amtrak hopes can fix crumbling bridges and tunnels along the Northeast Corridor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials up and down the East Coast have long agitated for money to help replace crumbling bridges and tunnels along the Northeast Corridor, the heavily traveled route between Washington and Boston. After decades of underinvestment, the $1 trillion infrastructure bill that President Biden signed last month is poised to deliver much-needed improvements.

articles.headline: ‘Q’ Has Been Quiet, but QAnon Lives On
articles.snippet: With the absence of a leader, the movement has transformed into more of a “choose your own adventure” conspiracy theory.
articles.abstract: With the absence of a leader, the movement has transformed into more of a “choose your own adventure” conspiracy theory.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 8, 2020, a few weeks after Joseph R. Biden was elected president, “Q” — the anonymous online account that set off the QAnon conspiracy movement — posted a link to a video with scenes of cars burning on the streets, fighter jets over a stadium and Donald J. Trump with his hand on a Bible, being sworn in as president. The images played over a song by Twisted Sister, “We’re Not Gonna Take It.”

articles.headline: Markets sink on Omicron fears and a critical setback on the U.S. spending plan.
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 fell amid grim forecasts about the Omicron variant and a setback in efforts to pass a comprehensive domestic policy bill.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 fell amid grim forecasts about the Omicron variant and a setback in efforts to pass a comprehensive domestic policy bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Markets sank on Monday, extending last week’s losses, as investors took in the latest grim forecasts about the sudden surge in the Omicron variant and after a big setback in President Biden’s efforts to pass a comprehensive domestic policy bill.

articles.headline: Biden Tries to Salvage Domestic Policy Bill After Rift With Manchin
articles.snippet: Senator Joe Manchin III criticized the White House staff for its handling of negotiations over the legislation, saying officials had pushed him to his “wit’s end.”
articles.abstract: Senator Joe Manchin III criticized the White House staff for its handling of negotiations over the legislation, saying officials had pushed him to his “wit’s end.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his top aides tried on Monday to salvage hopes of passing their domestic agenda, acknowledging that their only path forward is to repair a broken relationship with Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia after a personal and policy breach over the weekend that left the legislation all but dead in the Senate.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Michael D. Shear
